President Trump’s suggestion to delay the census indefinitely is outrageous and unconstitutional. Once again, he demonstrates his contempt for the rule of law and how little he knows about the document he swore an oath “to preserve, protect and defend."

At @capgaznews almost exactly 1 year ago, 5 innocent people died doing their jobs. They died while supporting a publication that has long held an unwavering commitment to preserving the freedom of speech in our community. Thank you @ChrisVanHollen for joining this tribute effort.

Every federal official, even @POTUS has sworn an oath to support and defend the Constitution of the USA. Freedom of the press is one of our most basic rights granted to us through the Constitution. We bear the solemn responsibility of defending freedom of the press.

We have monuments and memorials to honor those who have helped make our nation and our democracy stronger since its founding days. Currently missing from that honor roll are reporters who have sacrificed everything to report the news in the spirit of free/transparent societies.

Today w/@senrobportman I introduced legislation to create a National Memorial for Fallen Journalists. This new memorial will honor the brave souls lost in the shooting at the Capital Gazette one year ago and others who lost their lives doing their job in defense of our freedoms.

As the number of displaced persons worldwide continues to shatter records, I commend all those working in the US and around the globe to provide humanitarian assistance to the world's refugees. I will continue to support your work and your mission. #WorldRefugeeDay pic.twitter.com/OWQ8CNy3qA

Our nation has long served as a beacon of hope for those in search of freedom. To turn our backs on immigrants, refugees, and asylum seekers – no matter their religion, race, or nationality - is to turn our back on international law, American values, and basic decency.

It is cruel and inhumane to slam the door on refugees, to separate children from their parents when they are fleeing violence and persecution, and to cut funding to humanitarian and economic programs that could mitigate the very reason families are fleeing their home countries.

#WorldRefugeeDay is an opportunity to recognize the courage and strength of refugees and asylum seekers who are fleeing violence, war and other extreme events, searching for safer lives for themselves and their families. America's strength is in our values, including compassion.

The Senate needs to make the right decision about upholding American values and human rights. Lives are at stake. We should not allow any president to use emergency powers when an emergency does not exist.

America's strength is our values. We cannot remain complicit in the humanitarian disaster in #Yemen. Over 1000 have been killed as a result of the Saudi-led coalition attacks. Through commonsense gun safety reforms that would make background checks more efficient and close loopholes, I am confident we can do it. States that require background checks on all handgun sales have seen less than half as many mass shooting incidents as states without.

We can end the tragic cycle of violence, but it will require us to come together in full urgency and honesty. I know we can protect innocent Americans from further senseless gun violence while still protecting the constitutional rights enjoyed for hunting and self-defense.

According to the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, 181 Marylanders have been killed by gun violence since the House passed its legislation. 

Inaction should not be the norm when lives are at risk. We, as a nation, must stem the tide of bloodshed and the hatred that drives it.

Clay Mitchell also was responsible for firmly establishing UMMS, now the 3rd largest private employer in the Baltimore metro region, as an independent entity and a world-class medical facility. I offer my heartfelt condolences to his family. Our entire state mourns his passing.

I will always remember our debates when I was Speaker and Clay served as the Appropriations Chair for the House of Delegates. He may have described himself as ‘low-key’ but he was tough and provided us with fiscal leadership that left a positive imprint on our state.

Clay Mitchell will be missed. He was a dear friend, colleague and a dedicated public servant. His death is a great loss for our state and the Eastern Shore, which he loved with every fiber in his being.

If the gender wage gap were closed nationwide, it would cut the poverty rate for working women in half and add nearly a half trillion dollars to our economy. Recognizing women for their contributions to our society and economy makes sense for women, their families and our nation.

Nearly 250yrs of treating women as less than equal has taken a toll on the women of our nation, their families and our economy. As we celebrate 100yrs of women voting & earning a voice in our electoral system, let's dedicate ourselves to closing the gender gap wherever it remains

For 144 years, male-dominated legislatures kept women from casting a vote because they were looked upon as less than equal with men. Today, those same forces are trying to rein in women’s rights with respect to women’s access to reproductive health care.

How a nation treats its women is a barometer of that nation’s success. Empowering women is one of the most important things we can do for the future of our country. Core to this is the constitutional right women have to make their own choices about their own health and well-being

We must correct this injustice and finally recognize the equality of women under the law w/ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment. Congress can remove the deadline for ratification, which means only one more state would need to ratify the ERA for it to become law. #ERANow

Securing the vote was only the first step. 100 yrs later, more women are entering the workforce and more are filling leadership roles at record levels. But most Americans are shocked to learn the Constitution does not guarantee women the same rights/protections as men. #ERANow

The 19th Amendment was introduced more than four decades earlier, in 1878. It would take a little over one year until three-fourths of the states ratified the amendment, guaranteeing women the right to vote. https://www.cardin.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/cardin-celebrates-100th-anniversary-of-senate-ratification-of-the-19th-amendment …

On this day, 100 years ago, the United States Senate finally ratified what would be the 19th amendment to the Constitution, sending it to the states for ratification. The amendment prohibited the states and the federal government from barring women from voting.
